Evaluation_Questions: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken
What is your overall assessment of this course
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor
The primary instructor's provided students with helpful and timely feedback
The instructor established a positive learning environment
The instructor raised questions or problems that encouraged me to think critically
Comments_Questions: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course
Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved
Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
How would you summarize this course for a fellow student?  Would you recommend it to another student?  Why or why not
Comments_List: 1 hour
30 minutes
1 Hour
1 hour per week on weeks when the class met.
1-2, only offered at the end of the semester
3 hours
1, to do the required online training
1-2 hours.
about 1.5 hours in class, 3x during fall semester

Because this course only met three times at the end of a very busy semester, I spent maybe about 5-10 minutes per week skimming over the articles for class and thinking about the topics, and 2 hours total on the online certifications. However, had this course met during a different time in the semester, I would have spent more time and put more effort into it overall.
About 1 hour
1 ( I did the readings or at least skimmed them).
30 minutes for readings
~1 hour
class met only 3 times and during those 3 weeks it only took 1-1,5 hours to read required materials.
N/A
1h
About 2-4 hours to complete trainings and readings.
1 hour for the 3 week period
0-1 hours
I spent 2-3 hours per week reading the class materials in preparation for our lessons.
I spent about 1 hour total for the semester
3 hours

AP- 
0.5hrs of reading prep before each of the 3 sessions; colleagues often read during the section itself
AP 30 mins
The homework assignments (reading papers) before class took a few hours, but only during the weeks that we met for class.

the course was only held for 3 sessions during term. Prior to each session I spent approx 1-2 hours doing pre-reading. I spent approx 3 hours doing the required HIPAA training and Human subject protection training program.
1 (doing the readings) for the 3 weeks
1 hour per week
1-2 on weeks with sessions.
1 hour
1-2 hours before the seminar
Less than 1 hour/week averaged over the course of the semester
One Hour reading the assigned readings
It was OK. Useful information but wish it was presented in a better way, more like a lecture.
Would be much nicer to have the first three weeks of the semester rather than the last three, or as a longer class overall ( I think the material merits more than three hour and a half sessions)

Please put this course at the beginning of the semester. It's a necessary class but it was very inconvenient to have it be right before finals when every other class ramped all the way up to then have to add an extra class. People, including myself, made plans to travel and had to change them because the class dates were not announced well before the semester began or even at the beginning. These dates needed to be released during orientation so we could buy Thanksgiving tickets at a decent price rather than waiting until they became more expensive.
Good
Not useful, I was looking for TOOLS but instead it just felt more like debates every class.

The class was boring. I can see the importance and why it is a required class, however the course was boring. Also - Friday afternoon at the very end of the day - the last 3 Fridays of the semester was a drag. The TFs were terrible. No consistency - my particular pair of TFs were not good at facilitating discussion. Lots of awkward silences.

The timing of the course was very annoying. Having it late afternoon the last 3 Fridays of the semester was a bad idea. The format also made it hard to engage because we were thrown into pretty big sections with a lot of people we didn't know and were not given time to get to know them before we were asked to discuss highly fraught topics. It was poorly designed. Breaking out into small groups and then coming together might have been more useful.

I think this course should be extended into a semester and made as an actual requirement. Three short meetings are not enough to do the topic area justice. Additionally, people would scan into the course and just leave the auditorium. There needs to be more accountability for people and I think this could be done through a smaller class/seminar environment.

This topic is so interesting and important, but this class is effectively worthless.  I have heard great things about Kaveh, but the structure does not allow him to shine; and the student-led break-out sessions had no hope of succeeding given the short amount of time allotted and the complexity of ideas that theoretically should have been covered. I hope that YSPH will consider a significant refresh of this class.   (Sten's guest appearance was the only truly interesting aspect of this 3 session course.)

I strongly enjoyed the content of this course, however the timing of this course was largely problematic and prevented me from getting as much as I could from the course. The first class met the Friday evening before break, a day when YSPH first years otherwise did not have class. I was planning to leave Thursday night, but had to change my travel plans. The next two sections met during the final two weeks of class, arguably the busiest time of the semester. It seems like students were disengaged and most people in my section did not complete the reading. I think it would be far more beneficial to meet during orientation before classes start. Especially because some students (myself included) participate in research during their first semester, having an ethical mind state is imperative from the very beginning.
needs to be a full course split half and half with social justice
I wish this seminar would have been at the beginning of the semester not the last 3 weeks of class.

This is an excellent class and should be made into a normal, full-credit course! Three sessions is barely enough time to begin to scratch the surface of ethics, and the material is so compelling that it deserves much more time and should become a more significant part of the core courses. This was one of my favorite classes of the semester and it is a real shame that we get to spend so little time on this subject (especially considering the fact that there aren't many bioethics classes available outside of this).

I think it's very informative, but we should definitely of had the guest speakers speak the whole time and not split up the classroom. They were so interesting and informative and I don't think we needed the small classes to get people to participate. I would also front load the class by making it in the beginning of the semester instead of the end. The end of the semester is very busy and adding a course near the end did not help that.
I wish the course could have taken place closer to the beginning of the semester. The material could have served students well in their courses or outside research projects.

The small group discussions were super awkward and almost no one talked. The few who did speak were all just repeating themselves. Should not be on a Friday afternoon, especially before a holiday when people need to fly home.

I really enjoyed the class and the ethical questions we were asked to consider - I wish the class had been longer though; 3 weeks did not feel like enough to have the discussions I think are necessary to be well informed conscientious public health professionals.
It's good to help me learn about the interaction between ethics and public health issues.
It would have been good if classes were more spaced out- I wish we didn't have class right before Thanksgiving break

This seminar should have been an entire course. It was poor timing that they were held on the last three weeks of classes, on Friday afternoons. By that point in the semester, many students were already exhausted and unfocused. Having discussion in Harkness Auditorium was even worse. The readings were incredibly interesting, but also complex and it felt like the majority of our conversations were students just positing in lieu of learning. Meeting in separate rooms and then coming back were great in theory but only added to the disjoint and unengaging environment. Having the speaker come in the second seminar was the highlight of the course and could have been the model for the other three.
This was a very interesting course. It should be a required course.

Needs to be a half credit, half semester class!!!  Split this with social justice for the first years, each with a half credit.  These topics were way more interesting than our other classes, yet we didnt spend any academic energy on them.  Real world case studies are valuable to us!

Discussion sections with the TAs were lackluster...no one did the readings because there was no incentive.  Great topics, poorly executed.
fine but unnecessary course and the timing on Friday is silly.

This course is very valuable and important, but I wish it was scheduled at an earlier time in the semester. The late afternoon Friday courses before breaks created a sense of resentment before the class even started.

This is a very important topic but to cover it in three seminar sessions is not doing it justice. I think this should be a full semester course. Ethics should not just be 'brushed' on. It is insufficient. Yale has a responsibility to train future healthcare leaders in ethics and how to perform ethical practices and research and covering this extremely crucial topic in 3 seminar sessions is not enough. I was disappointed in the format of this course.

I felt that this class would have better served me as an addendum to an existing class (i.e. an ethics component attached to a research methodology class). In this way, it could have been more prolonged and we would have been able to get into more depth. As it was, this class only met three times during the semester and the meeting times were quite inconvenient (right before breaks, not really told to us at the start of the semester, at the end of the semester, etc.). It felt kind of like an afterthought. I would have appreciated a more formal, prolonged class. The professor was professional and knowledgeable and I really enjoyed his insight. I just wished I had more time.
The ethics requirement for accreditation should have been done differently. Not sure how, just that this method did not work well.
This was a useless course. I did not learn anything. The small groups were a waste of time
Pretty basic ethics class, especially if you have a background in medicine/law/industry/etc. Small groups weren't terribly helpful.

This is a very useful and thought provoking course in public health and I think it's important for everyone to take an ethics course in a public health graduate program. However, the odds for this course were stacked against it. This course required online certification and met during the last three Fridays of a painful semester. Few people were able to put in any significant amount of time and effort into this class because first year students were managing their other course requirements. I think this would have been a much more positive experience if the entire course was conducted during orientation or during the first two weeks of the semester when the workload was significantly lighter for first-years. I am confident that I would have gotten more out of this course and put more effort into this course had it been scheduled at any other point in the semester. 

That said, its biggest strengths are that the content is useful, interesting, and important.
Three sessions is not enough time to learn anything in any sort of deep and critical way. It felt like no one was really invested in this course, and this was reflected in what people got out of it.

I was honestly dreading taking this course, so I was honestly floored by how interesting it was. The guest speakers with direct experience in the discussed topics really brought life to the complexities of the issues at hand.

While it's always tough to organize a mandatory, no-credit course in a way that engages students, I think that scheduling class for the last three Fridays of the semester (in the middle of the holidays and finals) made it especially tough. I actually think that I'd prefer a one-day seminar/workshop format, where you rotate between different discussions with different speakers/facilitators.
too short; would better be a semester long course

I think that considering the course only ran for a few weeks, it did a good job but I wish the class was more extensive. I know that due to time constraints the curriculum had to be cut down a lot but I wish that this class went on for longer and could start with the philosophical foundations for ethics (e.g. consequentialism, utilitarianism, Kant) before delving into case studies. I think that case studies help a lot in terms of expanding ethics into the specifics of how ethics could apply to public health research and projects but I think it would have been nice to understand the theoretical framework because it would help students better learn and further apply what they learn beyond a few specific studies. But I do think that the case studies that were chosen were really helpful since those circumstances discussed are probably what most people in public health will encounter more, in comparison to other classical situations. I do think it would be really nice to have discussions also relevant to the biomedical world and established pieces of literature surrounding biomedical ethics decisions, e.g. "A Defense of Abortion" by Judith Jarvis Thomson, as I think these pieces would help guide public health students in how to think about ethics.

I LOVED THIS COURSE! PLEASE Make it a graded course in the future. I would take a full semester version of this if offered. I would recommend making it a required half semester course and making social justice the other half semester (bc there wasn't enough to cover a full semester there). Readings/ case selection/ speaker selection were all excellent though!

This needs to be a semester long course. Public Health has a very messy history of violent imperialism and ethical mishaps. We need to engage with this extensively and for longer. It should still be in the first semester or year. But if you keep it at 3 classes, then move it to the beginning of the semester so we can begin to engage with ethical dilemmas from the beginning. Alternatively, the semester long course can be Public Health History and Ethics. This past and current state need to be known in detail by students getting ready to go into the world and potentially make the same mistakes.

I really liked the case studies that were selected to discuss. I found this very interesting and thought provoking. I do wish that our discussion sections were a little longer as well as having more time to hear the speakers present. Maybe separating the discussion and the speakers would be more beneficial?
I would have this at the beginning or middle of the semester instead of at the end. Otherwise I loved kgb
n/a

I wish this course was taught in full. I understand the motivation to make it a quick overview in health issues, but I think I would have been more engaged and gotten more out of it if it were a full course. I think the topics we covered were fascinating, but the nature of it being a three-meeting course left many people disengaged. At the very least, I think that it would help to hold the class at the beginning of the year, in future years. As it fell during the end of the year, people were both busy/less willing to do the readings and were unable to apply what they learned to the courses we took this semester.

The large group sessions were informative and provoking. In particular, the guest lectures enhanced my understanding of the material. However, given that this was only 3 sessions, I felt that we really only skimmed the surface of bioethics. Perhaps this course would be better suited as a full semester class, or a day long seminar during orientation to be able to delve into the content more.
Good course, given the timing.
It was interesting. They should be integrating it into orientation or hold the sessions at the beginning of the year.
Course should not be held on the last few Fridays of the semester.
Very interesting course. Would have liked to have it at a different time other than Friday afternoon.

I believe that this course should either be offered in the first 3 weeks of the semester, or each of the sections should be spread out throughout the semester. Having it the last 3 weeks - especially given the proximity to the holidays - made it more difficult for people to attend.

I think this was a very poorly structured course. The timing of it also seems very odd (end of semester in the midst of thanksgiving break and finals). The small groups didn't benefit either because they were so short and took away time from listening to the instructor/guest lecturer. My TFs--Janine and Miriam-- were also very aggressive and condescending by telling our group to read next time, implying we hadn't, simply because not everyone participated (when in fact majority of the room did). It left a bad taste and aura in the group. I don't think trying to talk about ethics in research is possible in three sessions in a setting of 200+ students. Simply didn't add value.
N/A

Only three classes in the semester with the first one being held the Friday before Thanksgiving break was a poor choice. This class was interesting and though provoking but would have been more engaging if providing towards the beginning of the semester compared to the very end

Good overview of ethical issues in public health and global health. I think instead of having a 3 day series, the ethics portion of the MPH could just be incorporated into our classes like epi, health policy, social justice or environmental health. It'll make the material seem more relevant to our classes, and having three separate sessions toward the end of the semester when people were a bit burned out from school was a bit too much. I think this "class" had WAY too many TFs, which seemed like a waste of resource for the school. Incorporating ethics to our core public health courses, which I think is relevant and important, would be a better way to spend resources.
I think if the course is scheduled at the beginning of the semester, it would better. Ethics should be understood at the very beginning.

Course is essential for any researcher and even as a reminder course in the future. Discussion sections could have had more engagement from the TAs (too many long silences). Timing of course could have been better (Friday late afternoon before breaks)
good
Good course. Great discussions. However, there needs to be a way to hold students accountable for doing the readings.

This was an extremely interesting course that made me think more critically on ethical issues that I hadn't previously considered. My only criticisms are that I wish it was a more extensive course, and the room my discussion was in was not very suitable for its purposes (small, not enough chairs).
I understand it's only three sessions but it didn't feel cohesive across the three sessions.

I liked this course very much. The structure was great (the small discussion sessions, having guest speakers, interactive nature of the lecture). Only misfortune of it was the timing; one of the three classes was just before Thanksgiving, and the other one was before the winter break. I wish the course covered the whole semester as one hour classes, instead of three week style. There were not exams, so I really enjoyed the class without a stress factor accompanying me.
Interesting material, but not great timing as the lectures/seminars were during "high-stress" times (close to exams/breaks).

I think the course should have been offered at the beginning of the semester, and been more tied in with content from other courses. It felt a little throwaway, right at the end of the semester, when ethics in public health should really be a central topic.

I get that we had to do this class. But the organization was bad. We were put into groups that met twice. That did not foster a good environment to talk about ethics or speak opinions. It was poorly scheduled, also. Right before holidays and on late Friday afternoons when everyone was already gone from campus and had to come back. It could have been a good class to have good discussions, but it did not turn out that well. The last sessions when the Dean spoke was the only interesting part of the class, in my opinion.

Liked that this was only 3 sessions. I'm an AP student who has worked as a physician for several years so was a bit of a joke being taught medical ethics by a second year MPH student. But still, went through the motions to tick the box.
good

This course did not increase my knowledge or encourage me to think critically in a manner that is novel to the critical thinking that I already do in my career, education, and own free time. This course could be improved if it was offered as an online module that could be completed on one's own time, and even then this course would have little to no benefit to me if it was run in the same manner, and posed the same questions that it did this year. I gained nothing from this. This course could be improved if it dared to present more controversial material, and if it didn't seem like it was designed as an afterthought, probably to help fit public health certification standards. The only valuable part of this course was the interaction with dean, which was the best opportunity YSPH students have had to interact with him to date. Everything else should be scrapped and this entire course should be brought back to the drawing board. This really seemed like something for undergraduates or high school students who have never been introduced to ethics related to public health. I was very disappointed by the quality of this course, especially as the three Fridays chosen for it were the most inconvenient possible.
I really liked how the class was part seminar where we met in small groups and then part lecture where we met as an entire class.
This course was very engaging and made me think critically about ongoing ethics issues. The lecture and classroom environments were very conducive to open participation.
Shame that it only met 3 times. It would have been worth it to make it a full semester course because it's important to learn about ethics!!
Good but could be improved. I think having it earlier in the semester would be more helpful.
Poor. I learned nothing and was not impressed with the conversations held. The questions posed were leading questions and discussion was very one dimensional.

I think a huge weakness of this course was the timing of it. I think it should have been scheduled in the beginning of the semester as opposed to the end. Additionally, I didn't find the small group discussions very useful and I would have rather listened to the speakers for longer.
This course should be longer, at least half a semester.

AP-
Strengths: relevant, key topics; Prof Khoshnood welcomed lively discussion

Weaknesses: timing (selecting the pre-Thanksgiving Friday as one of 3 sessions), TF facilitation (while TFs were clearly very interested in the topics and were eager to promote discussion, their comments were very much one-sided, seemingly more antagonistic of the selected readings' ethical decisions; some comments certainly did not reflect ethical decision-making in the real world).

AP- It was hard to engage with this course given that it was on Friday afternoons, at the busiest time of the semester when I had multiple assignments due and exams to study for. It would be better to hold this at the start of the semester.
They are essential for students who would like to conduct research in the future.

I think it's a good conversational class overall, but it could be more challenging. I would expect that most students in the course have taken ethics or philosophy classes before, and we could dig a little deeper into some of the issues presented.

as a physician in the AP program this course was utterly useless. Having relatively extensive global health and clinical experience it was very frustrating to have TA's lead sessions who have had little real world experience. While the articles were interesting perhaps the small group format would've been better for the duration of each session. In the future, the TAs should have some more coaching and improved ability to lead a discussion (rather than read a list of pre-prepared questions). Other's in the MPH program may be more appropriate TAs for this course.
The lectures were interesting, but I felt like the discussions were kind of a waste of time. Most of the time was spent in silence since few people bothered to do the readings.

I really loved the overall topic of this course but did not like the structure or timing. This class would have been WAY  more useful/interesting at the beginning of the semester when we're beginning to look at research projects and specific studies not at the end of the semester close to holidays and finals. The content itself is incredibly interesting and worth more than 3 classes worth! However, I don't understand the point of the small sections with the TFs -the TFs in my class were frankly not helpful; the lecture part of the class was much more interesting and informative. 

The guest lecture by Lauren Taylor was fascinating and the discussion with Sten was also very very interesting - all lectures were very enjoyable!

This course was a little bit too short for the subject material in my opinion. We were often running out of time by the end of each period. The TF- led discussion sections were also a little difficult to get through. It was hard to get a cohesive discussion going with three TFs and 30 students. I found the lectures to be generally engaging.
I found the lectures interesting and the smaller group sessions allowed for more discussion and questions.
The topics/ papers  selected were excellent
Fantastic. I wish that bioethics were a full course (rather than 3 weeks). Fantastic discussion in the tutorial and lecture (with great speakers).

I thought the class was good and beneficial. It would have been nice to have the classes earlier in the year rather than it cramped in the last 3 weeks of the semester. But the material we learned was practical for future use.
The topics chosen are interesting and relevant, and the guest lecturers were all very good.
I wish this course was longer, honestly. It didn't seem like 4 sessions did it justice. However, the discussions were important and relevant and I think it covered all the bases.

strength: important topic
weakness: group discussions can be better moderated by the TFs

The material and content of the course was good: I did not appreciate that it was offered on three Friday afternoons at the end of the semester. It would be more appropriate to offer it at the beginning of the semester.

Very nice capstone to the the end of the semester. The case studies that were brought up were very thought provoking and timely. My only suggestion is that this be offered closer to the beginning of the semester, as most people were already thinking about thanksgiving and winter break, and almost everyone was already exhausted from studying for impending finals!

Strengths - Provided great intro to ethics in research specific to public health. Encouraged everyone to think critically and from personal experience. Enjoyed the speakers who came to discuss their own work with ethics and how they handled it. 
Weaknesses - Not enough courses, should go on throughout the semester.
Discussion section was helpful.

Awesome course!  Course shouldn't have been placed right before Thanksgiving, but the material was interesting and relevant to public health work.  Thought the Dean coming to speak to the class was a unique and interesting part of the course.
good class; however, should be conducted at the beginning of the semester opposed to the end when finals are near. discussion sections should have more structure.

This was an interesting course that allowed us to talk about important topics. However, I think that the format of the course could have been better designed because we always ran over time because we did not have time to discuss all that we needed to cover. I think the time spent in small groups could be reduced in order to give more time to the larger group. Also, having the course take place during the last three weeks of the semester was stressful because that is already the busiest time! I think it would be better to have the course during the first three weeks.

This is a great course, but would be more effective and enjoyable if it was placed during orientation or if it was more spread out throughout the semester. The weeks that this course was held were some of the most stressful towards the end of the semester, so I did not feel as invested in this course as I wanted to be.
I enjoyed the material, but I wished that the course would occur earlier in the semester when courseworks for other classes weren't as heavy.

The three weeks of this course were manageable. It was a good amount of time and broken into logical discussions. The three sessions allowed for unique talks on different issues. As well, while it is a huge course, people were incredibly engaged. By having small sections followed by large group discussions, it facilitated learning from a larger number of people and viewpoints. The only weakness of this course was the timing of the weeks. I think that by having it on Fridays incredibly late, especially right before Thanksgiving, it made it harder for people to be engaged.

I like the idea of the course. It's definitely important to have an ethics course, but this course was unstructured at times. It felt like we were going over a scattered variety of journal articles that had some sort of ethical component to them. It didn't seem like there were particular takeaways across all of them tying the different articles and classes together. Perhaps having us make a list of the main objectives at the beginning of  the course and then structuring each class according to those objectives could help. It might make sure that we all learned the main takeaways by the end of the course, and it can help focus the conversations in class.
Very interesting course!

The course needs to be longer. Having only three sessions for something as important as ethics is extremely problematic. People would scan the class code and walk out of the classroom, and it was clear that many students didn't care about the material. As someone who studied ethics in my undergraduate career, I found this to be quite disturbing. We need a course to make these topics more deeply understood and engaged in, but the way it is set up now made it seems like more of a bother to many students than anything else.
Honestly it was interesting and I like learning about this topic, but it was very frustrating to have it at the end of the semester right before thanksgiving and finals
Good introduction to HIPAA and ethical requirements for conducting ethical research on humans

This course is an absolute waste of time. I realize that the timing of the course was less than optimal - Friday evenings during the busiest time of the semester - however, the format of the course was not conducive to learning. The small group meetings with the 2 TFs were absolutely dreadful. The TFs were not engaging and none of the students spoke. We literally sat in the room for an hour in mostly silence. The large lecture was also similarly boring.

This class was utterly pointless, as I felt that I learned nothing that I didn't already know. The three sessions were ill-timed, as they were just prior to finals week. The TAs  and students in discussion sections all acted like they didn't want to be there.
I would have liked if this course were offered earlier in the semester and more frequently. Questions were though-provoking and the subject matter deserved more time to be considered fully.

The 2 small discussion groups held before the last 2 lectures of the class were great. They allowed for further discussion of the grey area in the ethical issues being raised. The large lectures were a little unhelpful because the class size was so overwhelming to discuss the items in question.
This course would have been better placed at the beginning of the semester rather than the end.

I appreciated having an ethics course incorporated into the MPH curriculum, especially one that did not take the full semester. I liked the individual discussion groups, but I'm not sure how coming back into a full class added more to the discussion groups. I would've rather spent more time in the discussion groups.
I enjoyed the lectures, especially the last one with Dr. Vermund. I think the TAs should be warned about asking leading questions and adding judgmental comments during discussion sections.
Good
He was fine.
The Professor was seemingly great. The cases that were selected were incredibly interesting, and I appreciated the variety of guest speakers who were brought in.
not much time spent with him
Professor Khoshnood is an excellent, thoughtful instructor. He clearly cares deeply about ethics in public health and built the class around thoughtful questions.
Professor Khoshnood is extremely well-versed in public health and ethical considerations of research and YSPH is quite lucky to have him. I am glad we had the chance to meet Dean Vermund as well.

Did a great job picking interesting material to discuss, good variety between weeks in what we talked about which engaged people from all backgrounds. Good use of bringing speakers in for discussions.
I think he's a good instructor. But since there are only three  times of classes overall, I don't learn much about the instructor.
The instructor often dominated the conversation and asked leading questions instead of letting students express their original opinions.
Very good instructor.
Seems great, not enough interaction to really say.
Great instructor
The professor was great. You can tell he is truly passionate about this topic and it shows.
Great! Excellent facilitator.
Seemed knowledgeable, much more so than the breakout group leaders.
Seems like a good professor

I think discussion sections could be improved by utilizing AP students as the TFs
Discussions were lacking and individuals with more experience could have provided a more worthwhile conversation

The instructor was very sensitive to the fact that the scheduling of this course was less than ideal and truly did his best to make the course a positive experience overall. I have no suggestions for Prof. Khoshnood to improve his teaching style, but I STRONGLY suggest changing the timing of this course, which would likely be a better experience for both the professor and the students.

Professor Khoshnood was a phenomenal moderator who did a fantastic job of facilitating discussion, and building on student comments to dig deeper into the material. I also really appreciated his curated readings--it did not go unnoticed that they were very brief, but also very interesting!

Kaveh was a really good professor! I think that he did a good job at challenging us and how we think about certain scenarios, especially by playing devil's advocate. I think he really pushed us during the short time that we had which was really amazing because with a topic that there are no right or wrong answers, it's best to learn how arguments are made and defended to learn more about how to make decisions when technically there isn't a right answer in how to go about it. Kaveh was really great!
Great! He sat in/ ended up partially leading my discussion section.
I enjoyed the professors take on the ethical issues raised. He did a great job at challenging students to think critically.
Such a great instructor for this course, knowledgeable and fun
He put a lot of effort and preparation into it. Interesting topics and conversations.
Excellent
Good facilitator.
He was a good speaker and asked great questions.
He was great.
Prof. Khoshnood  is a great lecturer, even if class met only 3 times, I learned a lot and enjoyed discussing ethics. wish it was a regular class instead of 3-weeks lecture series.
I liked him a lot (but it was only 3 lectures)
He was very eloquent, insightful and knowledgeable. He asked very good questions to prompt us to think critically.
Good.

Kaveh was a great instructor. He did pose some questions for thought that I never would have thought of myself doing research in communities. I liked that he invited others to come to speak; it showed that he really cared about teaching us as much as possible in the two class sessions that we had with him.
great
Dr. Khoshnood did a great job leading insightful discussions.
Dr. Khoshnood's sytle was very kind and caring. His approach to the topics and efforts to make the class more interactive was admirable.

He was very thoughtful and passionate about the topics. I think he chose good readings and lecture/discussion were interesting. I think he should have had the opportunity to introduce these topics at the beginning of the semester.
Good lecturer.
The class was excellently designed by Dr. Khoshnood.
Professor Kaveh made the lecture environment very open to communication, which encouraged participation and made the course very interesting.
Good instructor
Could be better.
excellently balanced
Can't really comment too much- he seemed to be a 'moderator' of the other speakers and material to a large extent.
He was easy to understand and engaging while leading the conversation.
Kaveh's lectures were awesome - great guest lecturerers too! the readings were well chosen and very interesting.
Professor Khoshnood ended up mediating one of my group's discussions and I found this format much more engaging than the TF- led sessions.
The instructor was knowledgeable and encouraged discussion.
He created a conducive environment for discussion
Fantastic. Encourage a lot of discussion and really addressed a wide range of issues.
very clear, very responsible, organize the course efficient
Prof. Khoshnood did a good job engaging the class on the terms of ethics. It can be a dense topic but he did a good job covering aspects I thought were beneficial to know.
The class was so large and there were so few sessions that I don't really have much feedback. The instructor did a good job.
helpful, knowledgable
We didn't really get to know him but he seemed competent.

Fantastic. Very good at provoking discussion, and probing into th subtleties of various issues. The last session where Dean Vermund came in for an impromptu presentation was low-key possibly the single best and most interesting presentation I had heard all semester, hands down. Very frank and illuminating.
Great instructor! Very interesting and enthusiastic about ethics and was very able to provide impactful personal experiences.
No issues - instructor was fantastic.
Awesome professor!  Provided interesting and clear materials.
great instructor. when he taught, the material was very engaging and informative.
Great instructor, very personable.
Really thoughtful and though-provoking

Kaveh is an incredible teacher and I feel blessed to have learned from him. He encourages people to be engaged and succeeds. He asks thought-provoking questions that can encourage many different viewpoints to arise. Despite different viewpoints, he always made it a safe space for people to speak. His ability to bring in different speakers during the last two weeks was great. There were no weaknesses.
Great instructor!
Well spoken, encouraged conversation, and very knowledgeable. Like I said above, though, he would have been much more impactful if we saw him every week instead of only three weeks.
He was interesting and raised good points.
Excellent
I'm sure the professor has passion for the subject but you could tell even he was struggling to be engaged on a Friday evening. He really tried but the class was not receptive.
I'm not sure who that is.
Dr. Koshnood was a very good facilitator.
This course has potential to be useful.
Good
Just something you have to get through.

This class should be very interesting, but as currently structured it is worthless.  No need to do the readings and no ability to discuss the readings even if you do them.  No value in participating because the time frame renders every discussion superficial.  I have heard good things about the professor, but he has no chance to shine given this structure.  You have to take the course, so advocate for a stronger structure, or just sit with friends near the exits and where nobody important can see you surfing the web.

I would summarize this course as an introduction to ethics, in which you learn how to have a conversation surrounding ethical dilemmas. I would recommend this course, however I would warn them that this class is strictly introductory and is not intended to be comprehensive.
need to change dates to earlier in semester. Horrible choice of dates.
This is a fantastic course!
I would recommend these sessions to fellow students as more people need to be having these ethical conversations.
Can be condensed to one long class and that it.
Yes. I think Ethics&Public Health is a vital important issue that everyone in School of Public health should learn about. And the discussion in this course is intersting and meaningful.
No, I would not recommend this course.
Short, required, low workload.  Hopefully this becomes a larger component to the YSPH core.
If you can place out, do. Any previous ethics class should count.
Yes, since it is crucial to a public health education but would want it to be a full semester course.
This presents a short introduction to the field of ethics in public health. Students can expect three lectures over the course of the semester and only a few reading assignments out of class.
I would recommend another student trying to exempt out if they have taken bioethics, as I have and should have done.
This course needs to reevaluate the timing of courses. It shouldn't be the friday before thanksgiving break.
Would be great if the first meeting of the course wasn't right before Thanksgiving. Pretty basic ethics course. If you're an AP student, try to waive out of it.

This course presents ethical frameworks relevant to public health work and examines the applications of these frameworks in real-life case studies. This is conducted in both large group and small group settings that foster various different kinds of conversations. I wold recommend the course to another student because I think public health ethics is an important topic. However, I would caution them on the practicality of adding another course at the end of a horrendously busy semester.
Not interesting. Poorly designed.

I would summarize it by saying that if you are looking for a class to teach you all you need to know about ethics for public health, this is not the class. I will still recommend it, especially for those who have already taken some sort of ethics class in the past but I think that this class needs to be strengthened and lengthened if the purpose is to produce public health students who know how to make ethical decisions or come to somewhat ethical conclusions.

A brief intro to ethics in public health. It is very applicable content for us to learn, as we will one day be likely encountering some of the ethical issues raised. I would recommend this another student.
This class is important as a public health professional and very interesting, it will make you think about problems you havent considered before
required
This course was a great introduction to bioethics for those who haven't taken a course on it.
A brief overview of ethics in public health. Good group discussion. Would recommend.
It's a good class that requires you to re-evaluate your actions for ethicality.
I would not recommend it to another student.
yes I would definitely recommend!
Yes-the guest lecturers were great

Though provoking about the ethics of research particular of where money comes from and how we should represent ourselves as scientists. I would recommend this class as other students should be able to consider these questions as well.
Important portion of the MPH training. Interesting readings and good discussions.
It introduced the ethics relating to research and study. It is helpful.

Ethics is what you think it is in regards to research and working with people; knowing the implications it can have on people and populations and being more sensitive and aware of your population of interest.
well established
Good course, low work load.

The course is what you make of it, especially considering how short it is. If you do the readings and actively participate in the discussions, I think you can walk away with new insight on ethical issues we may face in public health research and practice.
I would recommend this course to everyone since I believe that ethics is the cornerstone of health field.
I would probably recommend because ethics in public health is important.
I'd say it gives you a brief glance at ethics in public health. I would only recommend it if other, more comprehensive courses, weren't offered.
It's required. It was fine.
I would not recommend this course to a fellow student. This was a huge waste of my time, and a very poorly scheduled one at that. No critical thinking was stimulated by these discussions.
I would recommend the class to all first year student looking to gain an understanding of some of the ethical dilemmas that plague the healthcare field.
This course overviews the ethics in healthcare. I would recommend this course.
Introduces you to important concepts in ethics, but it is only an introduction

Bad and made worse by being at the end of the semester. It really feels like YSPH does not care about integrating ethics more effectively by deciding to pin this on the last three Friday afternoons of the semester when other courses are wrapping up and we have limited mental bandwidth to give to this class.

AP-
Touched on excellent, relevant, ethical topics; however, given the large class size, it was less useful. Would have welcomed additional 1-2 sessions.
Timing of individual sessions (the Friday before Thanksgiving) was sub-optimal. TFs with more balanced opinions (or more real world experience) would have been more helpful.
Compulsory ethics course. I found it interesting to hear from the dean at YSPH with regards to funding of research at the school.
This course offers you the guideline in conducting an ethic research
I would recommend a more complex ethics course that could also cover medical practice or research practice as a unit, rather than taking this course with the small number of meetings.
Very interesting but very cursory level. Wish we could go into more detail.
Overall the course was interesting and manageable
Thinking about really important ethical issues and why that it is important in the health sector.
good, useful
Yes I would recommend this class. It provides a solid foundation for ethics.
The case studies were interesting but the course itself is definitely not long enough to provide a solid ethics foundation for public health.
It's basically a crash course and discussion on the role of ethics and some of the tough questions in public health.
important topic, recommended but can be better managed esp for the small group discussions
It seems like this course was an afterthought in our first semester schedule, which is a shame because the content is very important for budding public health professionals.

Very short course that imposes little demand on your schedule or workload. Will require a few short, interesting readings. Very thought provoking. Make sure to appreciate what youre hearing and learning about, even if youre tired (I know I was...as mentioned before, this lands squarely before breaks, and during the height of course exam/project work, and finals studying).
Yes I would recommend this course. It is a great introduction to ethics in public health.
Yes - good intro to public health ethics for internship.
Interesting introduction into bioethics.
I would if the classes were better placed in the semester and if there was more content taught.
Yes, I would recommend it. It is a critical look into ethics in the public health world, and that is a crucial lens to have for any person wishing to work in or even understand that field.

This course is mandatory, but it is worth the time. Students were highly engaged in group discussions and it will make you think critically about conflicts of interest and ethical issues. As well, any opportunity to  have a class with Kaveh should be taken.

This is a course that teaches students about common ethical questions that arise in field of public health. This is a very important subject, and a more structured course work can help improve the class.
This course gives a brief overview of topics related to ethics in the field of public health. I would strongly recommend to another student.

Great material, but only in three tiny chunks. Take it in, engage with it, and get your peers to engage as well. Ethics are wildly important and we should all feel that way, especially going into public health.
Interesting topics but the timing is horrible. I hope they fix out that and people will be more engaged. You have to take it so thats that.
Thought-provoking course. Highly recommended
The case studies and readings are actually interesting but I would highly suggest a different format/time slot for this course.
A brief review of case studies on issues pertaining to public health.
Brief course about the important ethical issues in public health.
